PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Cardiac amyloidosis is a rare disorder that occurs when a substance called amyloid builds up in the heart. 2. Amyloid is an abnormal protein that is produced in bone marrow and can be deposited in various organs of the body. 3. Cardiac amyloidosis can affect the heart's ability to pump blood effectively. 4. The condition usually occurs in people between the ages of 30 and 60. Men and women are affected equally. 5. The cause of cardiac amyloidosis is unknown. 6. The following factors may increase your risk of developing cardiac amyloidosis: 7. Having certain inflammatory conditions, such as rheumatoid arthritis or inflammatory bowel disease 8. Having a family history of certain types of amyloidosis 9. Taking certain medications, such as anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), including aspirin 10. Having a kidney transplant, which may trigger the condition in people genetically predisposed to it 11. Having a condition called familial Mediterranean fever 12. Having a history of alcohol abuse 20. Having a history of a different type of amyloidosis 21. PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 1. Cardiac amyloidosis is a rare disease, but it is a major cause of death in patients with AL amyloidosis.2. The most common clinical symptoms of cardiac amyloidosis are fatigue and dyspnea, which are nonspecific.3. The most common physical finding is increased heart size, detected as a consequence of enlargement of the left ventricle, second left atrium, and/or right ventricle.4. The most common ECG abnormality is a low QRS voltage.5. The most common abnormalities on cardiac imaging are increased left ventricular mass and size, and increased left atrial size.6. The most common histopathologic finding is extracellular amyloid deposition, seen in all cardiac tissues.7. The most common finding on endomyocardial biopsy is extracellular amyloid deposition, seen in all cardiac tissues.8. The most common finding on abdominal fat pad aspiration is positive (i.e., amyloid present).9. The most common finding on rectal biopsy is amyloid deposition in the subepithelial tissues of the colon.10. The most common finding on skin biopsy is extracellular amyloid deposition, seen in all cardiac tissues.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: Migraine is a very complex disease, and there are many types of migraines.  The treatment options are also varied.  Some medications work on a particular type of migraine, while others are more broad spectrum.  It is important to know what type of migraine your daughter has, and what has been tried before.  There are also many non-medication options that can be tried.  A neurologist specialized in headaches would be the best person to help sort this out.  There is also a new field of headache medicine, and many academic centers now have headache specialists.

For patients with migraine-associated headache, triptans are more effective than NSAIDs at reducing headache severity and are associated with higher rates of headache relief and pain-free responses. 4. For patients with migraine-without-aura headache, NSAIDs are more effective than triptans at reducing headache severity and are associated with higher rates of headache relief and pain-free responses.

For example, triptans worked better for people whose migraines started without aura, and ergolines worked better for people whose migraines started with aura.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 10 mg per day of pyridoxine is considered safe during pregnancy.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. Yes, it is safe to take pyridoxine during pregnancy. Based on the available evidence, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) has given pyridoxine a "Purple" category rating, which means "Safe in pregnancy" and "Can be used without knowledge of the teratogenicity". 2. Pyridoxine is a form of vitamin B6. It is an essential nutrient that helps your body process proteins and carbohydrates. Pyridoxine also helps make red blood cells and helps your nervous system work properly. 3. Pyridoxine deficiency during pregnancy can cause seizures, skin rashes and depression. It can also cause a condition called hyperirritability syndrome, which is characterized by muscle twitching and weakness. 4. Pregnant women who are at risk for pyridoxine deficiency include those with a poor diet, those who are malnourished, vegetarians, women taking certain types of medications and women with gastrointestinal problems. 5. Pyridoxine is found in many foods, including meat, poultry, fish, bananas, whole grains, cereals and nuts. It is also available as a dietary supplement. 6. The recommended dietary allowance for pyridoxine during pregnancy is 2 mg per day.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 1. Yes, it is safe to use pyridoxine during pregnancy.2. Pyridoxine is a form of vitamin B6 commonly used as a nutritional supplement to treat or prevent low levels of this vitamin.3. Although there are no adequate controlled studies in pregnant women, pyridoxine is likely to be safe during pregnancy.4. Pyridoxine is indicated for pregnant women with anemia due to folate deficiency.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. Yes, it is safe to take pyridoxine during pregnancy.2. Pyridoxine is a form of vitamin B and is essential for normal functioning of the nervous system.3. It is also important for red blood cell, white blood cell and platelet production.4. Pyridoxine is used to treat a deficiency of the vitamin and to prevent its deficiency in patients receiving cancer treatment.5. Pyridoxine is also used in patients with homocystinuria, a condition in which the body produces high levels of homocysteine.6. High levels of homocysteine can cause a build-up of plaque in the arteries, increasing the risk of heart and blood vessel problems.7. Pyridoxine is in the vitamin B family of medications.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 1. Yes, Pyridoxine is an essential vitamin that is necessary for the proper development of the baby. 2. Pyridoxine is also used to prevent the baby from developing a condition called homocystinuria. 4. Pyridoxine is not known to cause any harmful effects to the baby and is considered safe for use during pregnancy.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1. Yes, pyridoxine should be avoided during pregnancy. 2. Pyridoxine passes into breast milk and may cause unwanted side effects in a nursing infant. Pyridoxine should be used with caution during breastfeeding. 3. Check with your doctor before giving this medication to a child.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: Hypothyroidism is a condition in which the thyroid gland does not make enough thyroid hormone to meet the body's needs. Thyroid hormone regulates metabolism—the way the body uses energy—and affects nearly every organ in the body. Without enough thyroid hormone, many of the body's functions slow down.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. Hypothyroidism is a condition in which the thyroid gland does not make enough thyroid hormone to meet the body's needs. 2. Hypothyroidism can be caused by problems with the thyroid gland or problems with the pituitary gland, which makes thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). 4. TSH tells the thyroid gland how much thyroid hormone to make. 5. Hypothyroidism can be: 6. Congenital, or present at birth. 7. Acquired, or developed after birth. 8. Muscle cramps. 21. A slow heartbeat. 22. High cholesterol levels. 23. Trouble sleeping. 24. A puffy face. 25. Swelling of the hands, legs, and belly. 26. A slow metabolism. 27. High levels of the hormone TSH in the blood. 28. Low levels of thyroid hormones in the blood. 29. PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 1. Hypothyroidism is a condition in which the thyroid gland does not make enough thyroid hormone to meet the body's needs. 2. Thyroid hormone controls how your body uses energy from food. It affects almost every organ in the body. 3. Hypothyroidism is often called underactive thyroid. 4. Hashimoto's disease is the most common cause of hypothyroidism. Hashimoto's disease is an autoimmune disorder. It means that your immune system attacks your thyroid gland. 5. Other causes of hypothyroidism include thyroiditis, thyroid surgery, radiation treatment of the thyroid, and certain medicines. 6. Symptoms of hypothyroidism include fatigue, weight gain, constipation, dry skin, and depression. 7. Women may have heavy periods and infertility. Men may have erectile dysfunction and loss of libido. 8. A child with hypothyroidism may have slow growth and development. 9. Your doctor will diagnose hypothyroidism with blood tests. Treatment is usually lifelong. You will need to take a pill every day to replace the thyroid hormone.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: Hypothyroidism is a condition in which the thyroid gland does not make enough thyroid hormone to meet the body's needs. Thyroid hormone regulates metabolism—the way the body uses energy—and affects nearly every organ in the body. Without enough thyroid hormone, many of the body's functions slow down.  Hypothyroidism is often called underactive thyroid. It is most common in women and often occurs between the ages of 20 and 50. People with a family history of thyroid disease or certain other autoimmune diseases are at higher risk for hypothyroidism.  Hypothyroidism is treated with thyroid hormone replacement medication. It usually takes a few weeks to months for the body to start making its own thyroid hormone again.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: Hypothyroidism is a condition in which the thyroid gland does not make enough thyroid hormone to meet the body's needs. Thyroid hormone regulates metabolism--the way the body uses energy--and affects nearly every organ in the body. Without enough thyroid hormone, many of the body's functions slow down.  Hypothyroidism is often called underactive thyroid.  Hypothyroidism can be caused by problems in the thyroid gland or by other health conditions. Most often, hypothyroidism is not caused by a disease. Instead, it is caused by one of three things:  - Hashimoto's disease, also called chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis  - thyroid surgery or radiation treatment to the neck  - certain medicines that can affect the thyroid gland  Some people develop hypothyroidism because they have an iodine deficiency. Iodine is an essential mineral that the thyroid gland needs to make thyroid hormone. Not enough iodine in the diet can cause the thyroid gland to make less thyroid hormone.  Other causes of hypothyroidism include the following:  - Congenital (birth) defects of the thyroid gland  - Pregnancy  - Thyroiditis (swelling and inflammation of the thyroid gland), which may be caused by a virus or certain medicines  - Radioactive iodine used to treat an overactive thyroid gland  - Certain medicines, such as lithium  - Iodine deficiency  - Surgery or radiation treatment to the neck  - Chronic thyroiditis or Hashimoto's disease  - Pituitary gland tumor  - Certain genetic diseases  - A diet too low in iodine  - A diet too high in goitrogens (foods that interfere with thyroid hormone production)  - A diet too high in soy products   Hypothyroidism may cause the following symptoms:  - Weight gain  - Fatigue  - Constipation  - Dry skin  - Hair loss  - Depression  - Puffy face, hands, and feet  - Intolerance to cold  - Menorrh
PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1. Hypothyroidism is a condition in which the thyroid gland does not make enough thyroid hormone to meet the body's needs. 2. The thyroid is a butterfly-shaped gland located at the base of the throat, just above the collarbones. 3. Thyroid hormones help control how the body uses energy from food. They also help make proteins and make sure the body has normal growth and development. 4. The thyroid uses iodine to make thyroid hormones. 5. Hypothyroidism is more common in women and people over age 50. 6. Hypothyroidism is often not noticed or is mild. Symptoms can be vague and can include tiredness, weight gain, constipation, dry skin, and depression. 7. The diagnosis of hypothyroidism is based on thyroid function test results. These tests measure the amount of thyroid hormone in the blood. 8. Treatment for hypothyroidism involves taking a pill every day that contains the missing thyroid hormone. Most people need to take the pill for life.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: Lewy body dementia is a type of dementia that involves abnormal protein deposits (called Lewy bodies) in the brain.  Lewy bodies are found in the brains of people with Parkinson's disease, but the brains of people with Lewy body dementia also show other changes that are similar to Alzheimer's disease.  Lewy body dementia is characterized by changes in:  - Mental abilities, including changes in awareness, alertness, and orientation  - Ability to carry out daily activities  - Physical abilities  - Personality and behavior  - Sleep habits  - Some people with Lewy body dementia also have Parkinson's disease, which causes tremors, rigidity, and difficulty with balance and walking.  Lewy body dementia is caused by the accumulation and death of cells in specific areas of the brain.  Lewy body dementia is most often found in people over age 60, but it can occur at any age. Men are affected more often than women. Lewy body dementia is usually not inherited, but researchers are looking into whether the genetic pattern may play a role in some cases.  Lewy body dementia is often misdiagnosed as Alzheimer's disease or Parkinson's disease.  Lewy body dementia is usually treated with drugs used for Alzheimer's disease, including donepezil (Aricept), rivastigmine (Exelon), and galantamine (Razadyne).  The main drug used to treat Parkinson's disease, levodopa, may make Lewy body dementia worse.  Physical therapy may help reduce muscle stiffness and improve balance and coordination.  People with Lewy body dementia often have trouble sleeping. Avoiding daytime naps and getting regular exercise may help.  Lewy body dementia is most often misdiagnosed as:  - Alzheimer's disease  - Parkinson's disease  - Vascular dementia  - Frontotemporal dementia  - Normal aging  - Stroke  - Recommendations for managing Lewy body dementia include:  - Keeping the environment familiar  - Using a nightlight  - Helping the person move around safely

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 3 copies of the gene that is mutated in SCA3 are present in each cell. People who have SCA3 develop symptoms when the number of copies of the mutated gene in a cell reaches a critical level. The specific symptoms depend on the organ systems most affected by the disease. The age of onset and the severity of symptoms can vary greatly from person to person.  People with SCA3 usually develop symptoms in adulthood, but some people develop symptoms in childhood.  The first symptoms are usually problems with movement. People with SCA3 often have difficulty with walking, balance, and coordination. They may develop tremors or shaking. Some people also develop stiffness in their limbs or trunk. People with SCA3 often develop problems with eye movement. They may have difficulty looking in a certain direction or have other problems with eye movements. People with SCA3 often develop problems speaking or swallowing. They may have slurred speech or difficulty articulating words. Some people with SCA3 also develop cognitive problems. They may have difficulty remembering things or have problems planning and organizing.  People with SCA3 often develop muscle problems. They may have muscle cramps or twitching (fasciculations). Some people also develop muscle weakness or wasting (atrophy). People with SCA3 often develop problems with urination, including urinary frequency, urgency, or incontinence. They may also develop constipation. Some people with SCA3 develop heart problems, such as an irregular heartbeat or slow heart rate (bradycardia). They may also develop high blood pressure (hypertension).  People with SCA3 often develop sleep disturbances, such as insomnia or restlessness. They may also have abnormalities in their sleep patterns, such as a tendency to fall asleep during the day (hypersomnia) or difficulty staying awake while driving or working (excessive daytime sleepiness).  Some people with SCA3 develop skin changes, such as a rash or thinning of the skin (atrophy). They may also develop acanthosis nigricans, dark, thickened patches of skin on the armpits, neck, or groin.

Introduction: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic systemic inflammatory disease characterized by persistent polyarthritis, which results in joint destruction and disability. 2. Objective: To investigate the clinical presentation of RA in a Chinese population and to identify the factors related to the clinical outcome. 3. Methods: A total of 1,000 patients with newly diagnosed RA (according to the 1987 criteria of the American Rheumatism Association) were enrolled in this study. 4. Results: The mean disease duration at the time of study was 5.0 +/- 5.5 years. The mean age at disease onset was 37.2 +/- 12.0 years, and 84.0% of the patients were female. The clinical presentations of RA in the Chinese population were similar to those in Caucasian populations. The patients with high disease activity, persistent synovitis, and poor treatment compliance had a worse clinical outcome. 5. Conclusions: The clinical presentations of RA in the Chinese population were similar to those in Caucasian populations. High disease activity, persistent synovitis, and poor treatment compliance were related to a worse clinical outcome.

In general, the small joints of the hands and feet are involved first, and as the disease progresses, larger joints such as the elbows, shoulders, ankles, and knees become affected. 5. In most cases, the disease is a chronic one, characterized by exacerbations and remissions.

The onset of RA symptoms can vary widely, from a gradual onset over a period of weeks or months to a sudden onset over the course of a few days. The initial symptoms are usually joint pain, swelling, and morning stiffness in the affected joint or joints. The joints affected most commonly in the early stages of RA are the small joints of the hands and feet. The initial pattern of joint involvement may be monoarticular (affecting a single joint or joint compartment) or oligoarticular (affecting 2 to 4 joints or joint compartments). In some patients, the initial presentation may be polyarticular, with symptoms in 5 or more joints or joint compartments.

It usually develops after 10 to 20 years of having diabetes.  3. High blood glucose levels can also damage the nerves. This damage is called diabetic neuropathy. It usually develops after 10 to 20 years of having diabetes.  4. People with diabetes are also at higher risk for heart attack, stroke, and circulation problems. They are also at higher risk for infections.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: Wellbutrin HCL XL is a type of antidepressant that belongs to a class of drugs called selective serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SSNRIs). Stopping treatment with Wellbutrin HCL XL suddenly can cause you to experience certain symptoms such as anxiety, irritability, and dizziness. These symptoms are usually mild and go away within a few days. Your healthcare provider will likely decrease your dose of Wellbutrin HCL XL over the course of one to two weeks before stopping the medication. If you experience any of the following symptoms, call your healthcare provider immediately: agitation, hostility, anxiety, panic attacks, phobias, hallucinations, depression, suicidal thoughts or actions, or pregnancy.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: Wellbutrin HCL XL should not be abruptly discontinued without a tapering process. Sudden discontinuation of Wellbutrin HCL XL may cause a discontinuation syndrome, which can be characterized by the following symptoms: anxiety, irritability, hostility, agitation, tremor, headache, sweating, palpitations, chills, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or insomnia. These symptoms are usually mild and are reversible upon reinstitution of Wellbutrin HCL XL or a reduction in the discontinuation rate. However, there may be serious consequences including seizures in certain patients. Patients should be cautioned against abrupt discontinuation of Wellbutrin HCL XL.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. Abrupt discontinuation of Wellbutrin HCL XL can cause symptoms like anxiety, agitation, irritability, hostility, tremors, and decreased sleep. 2. These symptoms usually start within a few days of stopping the PMC-LLaMA. 3. They usually resolve within 2 weeks. 4. It is usually recommended that you taper off Wellbutrin HCL XL slowly over a period of at least 2 weeks (approximately 25% of the current dose every 3 to 4 days). 5. However, if you have been taken off Wellbutrin HCL XL without a taper, and you're concerned about the potential risks, you can talk to your doctor about the risks and benefits of the medication.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: Wellbutrin HCL XL is an antidepressant used to treat major depressive disorder and other conditions.  It works by changing the actions of chemicals in the brain.  This medication is used to treat depression and should not be used to treat anxiety or psychosis.  Wellbutrin HCL XL is an extended-release tablet.  It is usually taken once or twice a day with or without food.  The dosage of Wellbutrin HCL XL is based on the patient's weight, age, and general health.  The extended-release tablets should be swallowed whole.  Chewing, dividing, or crushing the extended-release tablets can cause an overdose.  This medication should be taken at the same times each day.  It may take 4 weeks or longer before the full effects of this medication are seen.  Continue to take this medication even if you feel well.  Do not stop taking this medication without talking to your doctor.  If you suddenly stop taking this medication, you may experience withdrawal symptoms such as anxiety, agitation, or trouble falling asleep or staying asleep.  Your doctor will probably decrease your dose gradually.  Consult your doctor or pharmacist if you have any questions about how to stop taking this medication or what to do if you miss a dose.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: Wellbutrin HCL XL should not be abruptly discontinued without tapering. Sudden discontinuation of Wellbutrin HCL XL may cause withdrawal symptoms including paranoia, anxiety, agitation, depression, and suicidal thoughts. To avoid these symptoms, the dose of Wellbutrin HCL XL should be gradually reduced when discontinuing treatment. Consult your prescribing physician for more information.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. Plavix may cause side effects. Tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: dizziness, headache, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, stomach pain, indigestion, flatulence, heartburn, muscle or joint pain, tiredness, or weakness. Some side effects can be serious. If you experience any of the following symptoms, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help: skin rash, itching, hives, swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, mouth, or hands, difficulty breathing or swallowing, hoarseness, joint pain, or stiffness. Plavix may cause other side effects. Call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication. 2. Linisopril may cause side effects. Get emergency medical help if you have any of these symptoms: headache, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, loss of taste, itching, rash, hives, or swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, mouth, or hands. 3. Simvastatin may cause side effects. Get emergency medical help if you have any of these symptoms: muscle pain, tenderness, or weakness, especially if you have a history of muscle problems such as myopathy or myositis. Your doctor will monitor you for muscle side effects by checking your reflexes, muscle strength, and liver enzyme levels. This medication may also cause muscle weakness or tiredness. 4. Melatonin may cause side effects. Get emergency medical help if you have any of these symptoms: headache, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, drowsiness, sleepiness, shaking, irritability, or other mental or mood changes.

This medication may cause bleeding/bruising. Take care to avoid injury. Report any unusual bleeding to your doctor promptly. 4. This medication may cause a decrease in the amount of sex hormones produced by your glands. This may result in a decrease in breast size, breast tenderness, and an inability to produce or sustain a menstrual cycle. You may have a decrease in your ability to have children. These effects are reversible when the medication is stopped. Discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor. 5. Melatonin may cause drowsiness. Alcohol, hot weather, and fever may increase these effects. Caution is advised when driving, operating machinery, or performing other dangerous activities. 6. Lisinopril may cause side effects. See your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: cough, dizziness, headache, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, stomach pain, indigestion, back pain, joint pain, or fever. 7. Simvastatin may cause side effects. See your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: muscle pain, weakness, or cramps. 8. This medication may cause other side effects. Call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while you are taking this medication.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare disease and occurs due to defect in Microsomal Triglyceride Transfer Protein (MTTP).2. The condition is characterized by very low levels of cholesterol and triglycerides in the blood.3. Symptoms include failure to thrive (slow growth and development), diarrhea, vomiting, poor feeding, and fat malabsorption.4. Symptoms of vitamin deficiencies include:a. Dry skin,b. Difficulty feeding,c. Poor growth and development,d. Delayed puberty,e. Light sensitivity (photosensitivity),f. Difficulty walking,g. Muscle weakness,h. Seizures,i. Hearing and vision loss,j. Dementia,k. Liver and spleen enlargement.5. The diagnosis can be confirmed by genetic testing of a blood sample.6. Treatment is based on supplying enough lipids and fats to meet caloric needs.7. Supplements of fat-soluble vitamins (vitamins A, D, E, and K) are also necessary.8. Other treatments include:a. Restricting long-chain fatty acids in the diet,b. Providing medium-chain triglycerides (MCT),c. Providing essential fatty acids (EFA),d. Monitoring growth and development.9. Prognosis is poor.

The first step in diagnosing abetalipoproteinemia is to perform a complete physical skin exam to check for any signs of fat malabsorption, such as yellowing of the skin or whites of the eyes. 3. Other diagnostic tests that may be ordered include: - Blood tests to check for low cholesterol and triglyceride levels, anemia, and changes in liver function - Stool analysis to check for undigested fat - Endoscopy to examine the inside of the stomach and small intestine - Genetic testing to look for mutations in the MTTP gene 4. Treatment options for abetalipoproteinemia may include: - Dietary changes to reduce fat intake - Vitamin supplements to prevent deficiencies - Pancreatic enzyme replacement to aid in fat digestion 5. You can also seek support from organizations such as the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDK), which offers information about abetalipoproteinemia and other digestive diseases.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1.  Pre-pregnancy counseling: Women who are planning pregnancy should be counseled regarding risk factors and symptoms of preeclampsia. 2.  Prevention of Gestational Diabetes: It is well known that women who develop gestational diabetes are at increased risk of developing preeclampsia. Hence, prevention of gestational diabetes by screening all women at 24-28 weeks of pregnancy for glucose intolerance will help to reduce the incidence of preeclampsia. 3.  Prevention of Urinary Tract Infection: Women who develop urinary tract infection (UTI) in the first trimester are at increased risk of developing preeclampsia. Hence, prevention of UTI by screening all women at 12-16 weeks of pregnancy for UTI will help to reduce the incidence of preeclampsia. 4.  Early Detection of Preeclampsia: Early detection of preeclampsia will help to prevent its occurrence. 5.  Early Detection of Chronic Hypertension: Women with chronic hypertension are at increased risk of developing preeclampsia. Hence, early detection of chronic hypertension by screening all women at 20-24 weeks of pregnancy for blood pressure will help to reduce the incidence of preeclampsia.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1) Maintain a healthy weight before pregnancy. 2) Eat a well-balanced diet. 3) Get regular exercise. 4) Avoid tobacco, alcohol, and caffeine. 5) Get regular prenatal care and follow your provider's treatment recommendations. 6) If you have high blood pressure, get treatment.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 1) Screening for risk factors and initiating appropriate interventions to decrease risk. 2) Identifying pregnancies at risk through the use of biochemical markers and/or Doppler ultrasound. 3) Improved methods of fetal surveillance. 4) Improved methods for assessing the function of the placental unit. 5) New methods to prevent the placental oxidative stress and reduce the maternal inflammatory response. 6) Development of new pharmacologic agents that reduce the incidence of preeclampsia.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1) If you are at high risk for preeclampsia because of your age, weight, previous pregnancies, or medical problems, talk to your doctor about getting regular blood pressure checks and other tests. 2) Take steps to prevent or control high blood pressure, such as the following: a) Eat a diet that is low in fat and high in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains. b) Get regular exercise. Aim for 30 minutes of exercise most days of the week. c) If you are overweight, work on losing weight. d) Limit the amount of sodium (salt) you eat each day. Aim for less than 1,500 mg per day. e) Limit how much caffeine you drink. 3) If you are pregnant, do the following: a) Get regular prenatal care. Talk to your doctor about how often you should be checked and about how to prevent or control high blood pressure. b) Try to control any chronic health problems you have, such as diabetes or kidney problems. c) If you are at risk for preeclampsia, your doctor may prescribe a medicine called low-dose aspirin. You may also get a shot of a medicine called 17-alpha-hydroxyprogesterone acetate (Makena) to help prevent preeclampsia.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. The treatment of colon cancer depends on the stage of the disease and whether it has spread outside the colon. 2. Surgery is the main treatment for colon cancer that has not spread. The doctor may remove the part of the colon that contains the tumor, as well as nearby lymph nodes. 3. If the cancer has spread to other parts of the body, the doctor may recommend chemotherapy or radiation therapy. 4. In some cases, the doctor may recommend a procedure called an ostomy. With an ostomy, the patient has an opening (stoma) in the abdomen where the colon and/or small intestine can be attached to a bag outside the body. The bag collects stool or urine, which can be emptied into a toilet or a special bag. 5. The doctor may also recommend that the patient get a vaccine to prevent colon cancer from developing in the remaining part of the colon.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. Yes, there has been a recent tv commercial about a colon cancer cure that I'm aware of.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 1. Colon cancer is a disease in which malignant cells are found in the colon. The colon is the large intestine (the lower part of the digestive tract). Symptoms of colon cancer may include a change in bowel habits, changes in stool color, blood in the stool, and unexplained weight loss. 2. Risk factors include age over 50, a family history of colon cancer, and inflammatory bowel disease. 3. The diagnosis is made by a physical exam, blood tests, and a colonoscopy. 4. Treatment depends on the stage of the cancer and may include surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy. 5. Most people are cured by surgery to remove the cancer. Some people may need additional treatment after surgery. 6. The prognosis depends on the stage of the cancer and whether the cancer has spread.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 1. Colon cancer is not a common disease, and it is unlikely that a single treatment will cure all types of colon cancer. 2. The most common treatment for colon cancer is surgery to remove the part of the colon that contains the tumor. 3. The doctor may also recommend chemotherapy or radiation therapy after surgery. 4. If the cancer has not spread outside the colon, the doctor may remove the tumor and some of the surrounding tissue. 5. If the cancer has spread, the doctor may recommend a combination of treatments. 6. The doctor may also recommend a procedure called a colostomy to remove blockages in the colon. 7. A patient with stage 3 colon cancer may have a better chance of being cured if the cancer is removed by surgery rather than treated with chemotherapy and radiation therapy first. 8. In stage 4 colon cancer, the goal of treatment is to help the patient feel better and live longer. 9. The doctor may recommend chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and/or surgery to remove blockages in the colon. 10. Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other types of treatments to keep cancer from growing and spreading. It can be used in addition to chemotherapy and radiation therapy.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1. There is no known cure for colon cancer. 2. There are many claims for colon cancer treatments, but none of them have been proven to work. 3. Your father should talk to his doctor about getting screened for colon cancer. 4. If he does have colon cancer, he should talk to his doctor about treatment options.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1) Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is a condition in which the heart muscle becomes abnormally thick (hypertrophied). The thickened muscle can make it harder for the heart to pump blood. 2) Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) is a condition in which the heart muscle becomes weakened and enlarged. Blood is unable to be pumped out of the heart properly.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is a condition in which the heart muscle becomes thick. Often, only 1 part of the heart is thicker than the other parts. 2. Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) is a condition in which the heart muscle becomes weaker and enlarged. As a result, the heart cannot pump enough blood to the body.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 1. The heart has four valves. When the valves do not function properly, the condition is known as valve disease. The heart valves may not function properly due to a birth defect, infection, inflammation, or as a result of aging. 2. The most common valve problem is a leaky (regurgitant) valve. Less commonly, the valve may become narrow (stenotic). 3. The mitral valve is located between the left atrium and the left ventricle. When the mitral valve does not close properly, blood flows backwards from the left ventricle into the left atrium. This is known as mitral regurgitation. 4. The aortic valve is located between the left ventricle and the aorta. When the aortic valve does not close properly, blood flows backwards from the aorta into the left ventricle. This is known as aortic regurgitation. 5. The tricuspid valve is located between the right atrium and the right ventricle. When the tricuspid valve does not close properly, blood flows backwards from the right ventricle into the right atrium. This is known as tricuspid regurgitation. 6. The pulmonary valve is located between the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery. When the pulmonary valve does not close properly, blood flows backwards from the pulmonary artery into the right ventricle. This is known as pulmonary regurgitation. 7. Mitral valve prolapse occurs when one or both of the mitral valve leaflets bulge back into the left atrium during the cardiac cycle. This can cause mitral regurgitation. 8. The most common cause of valve disease is a defect in the valve that is present at birth (congenital). 9. Infective endocarditis is an infection of the heart valves caused by bacteria (more common) or fungi (less common). 10. Valve disease can also be caused by inflammation of the valves (valvulitis). 11. As people age, their valves may become thickened and calcified (valvular calcification). This is a common cause of valve narrowing (stenosis). 12.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. Heart conditions: Heart conditions are a broad category of disorders affecting the heart. The heart is a muscular organ that receives blood from the veins and ejects it into the arteries. The heart pumps oxygen-rich blood to the body's tissues and removes waste carbon dioxide. Some common heart conditions include:   • Heart disease (CAD) - Coronary artery disease is a condition in which the arteries that supply blood to your heart become narrowed or blocked. This is caused by the buildup of plaque inside the walls of the arteries.  • Heart failure - Heart failure is a condition in which the heart cannot pump enough blood to meet the body's needs.  • Arrhythmia - An arrhythmia is a problem with the rate or rhythm of the heartbeat.  Some types of arrhythmias can be life-threatening.   • Heart valve disease - Heart valve disease is a disorder in which the heart's valves do not function properly.  • Congenital heart defects - A congenital heart defect is a problem that is present at birth. It results from the heart's failure to develop correctly before birth.  • Angina - Angina is chest pain or discomfort that occurs when your heart is not receiving enough oxygen-rich blood.  • Pericarditis - Pericarditis is an inflammation of the sac around the heart.  2. Tests: There are several tests used to diagnose heart conditions. Some of the more common ones are:   • Echocardiogram - An echocardiogram uses sound waves to create images of your heart. This test can show if your heart is working normally or if there are any abnormalities.  • Electrocardiogram (EKG or ECG) - An electrocardiogram is a test that measures the electrical activity of your heart. It can show abnormalities in the heart's rhythm or in the heart's electrical conduction system.  • Stress test - A stress test measures the response of your heart to stress. It usually involves walking or jogging on a treadmill while hooked up to an EKG machine.  • Cardiac catheterization - A cardiac catheterization is a procedure used to diagnose
PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 1. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is a condition in which the heart muscle becomes abnormally thick. As a result, the heart becomes enlarged and has difficulty emptying itself of blood. Symptoms vary from none to feeling tired, leg swelling, and shortness of breath. Complications include heart failure, an irregular heartbeat, and sudden death. 2. Long QT syndrome is a group of rare, inherited heart conditions that have a defect in the electrical system of the heart which can cause episodes of fast, chaotic heartbeats (called tachycardia) which may cause fainting and sudden death.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1. Congenital heart disease (CHD) is a problem with the structure of the heart that is present at birth. There are many types of CHD. Some are very mild and may never cause symptoms or problems, while others can be life-threatening. 2. Heart conditions in children are common and can be caused by a number of factors. The most common cause of heart conditions in children is congenital heart disease. 3. Symptoms of heart conditions in children may include: - Rapid or irregular heartbeat - Rapid breathing - Bluish skin or lips - Fatigue with physical activity - Frequent respiratory infections - Shortness of breath - Heart failure 4. Diagnosis of heart conditions in children may include: - ECG - Echocardiogram - Cardiac CT scan or MRI - Cardiac catheterization 5. Treatment of heart conditions in children may include: - Medications - Surgery - Cardiac catheterization - Pacemaker or AID device

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. The first thing to do is to get a CT or MRI scan of the brain to determine the cause of the stroke.2. The treatment of stroke depends upon the type of stroke.3. If the stroke is caused by a blood clot, the treatment is to dissolve the clot. This is done by giving medications such as tissue plasminogen activator (TPA).4. If the stroke is caused by a blocked artery, the treatment is to either dissolve the clot or remove it.5. If the stroke is caused by a bleeding vessel, the treatment is to stop the bleeding.6. In all cases, the treatment is urgent.7. Treatment of stroke also includes preventing another stroke in the future.8. This includes treating high blood pressure, high cholesterol, and stopping smoking.9. It also includes starting aspirin or other blood thinners.

The most common heart defect is a narrowing of the aorta (coarctation of the aorta). PMC-llama13b_answer_original: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease characterized by chronic inflammation, demyelination, gliosis (scarring), and neuronal loss.  The most common course of the disease is the relapsing-remitting subtype, which is characterized by unpredictable acute attacks (relapses) followed by periods of relative remission with no new signs of disease activity (remission).  The other type is progressive subtype, which is characterized by a steady functional decline from disease onset.  The etiology of MS remains unknown.  The prevailing hypothesis is that MS results from an autoimmune attack on the central nervous system (CNS), triggered by an infectious or environmental stimulus in genetically susceptible individuals.  The disease is marked by distinct episodes of clinical inflammation, separated in time, with at least 30 days between attacks.  The clinical deficits resulting from an attack may resolve or leave sequelae, such as weakness or numbness, that disappear or worsen over time.  Between attacks, patients may be neurologically normal, or may have residual deficits from previous attacks.  The diagnosis of MS requires evidence of damage to the CNS, based on clinical deficits and/or abnormalities on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).  Two objective measures are required to attribute a deficit to MS:  Objective clinical findings (e.g., aphasia, agraphia, or hemianopia) must coincide with an objective measure of damage to the CNS (e.g., an MRI scan showing multiple white matter lesions).  A second objective clinical deficit (e.g., a second visual field defect) in combination with a second objective measure of CNS damage (e.g., a second MRI scan showing additional white matter lesions) is required to attribute a deficit to MS.  In the absence of objective evidence of CNS damage, a diagnosis of MS cannot be made. 10% to 20% of individuals with MS have a first attack as a teenager; in these cases, a history of optic neuritis (ON) or myelitis is often obtained.  The onset of MS can be abrupt or insidious,

The other type is progressive subtype, which is characterized by a steady functional decline from disease onset.  The etiology of MS is unknown, but it is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors.  The diagnosis is based on clinical evaluation and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).  Treatment is based on the course of the disease.  In relapsing-remitting MS, disease-modifying agents reduce the biological activity and frequency of relapses.  In progressive subtype, immunomodulators and immunosuppressants are used to reduce the biological activity.  In both cases, symptomatic treatment is used to manage pain, bladder dysfunction, and spasticity.  Overall, the prognosis of MS is quite variable, and it is difficult to predict the course of the disease in any individual patient.  The disease can be quite disabling in some patients, while others can maintain a relatively normal lifestyle for many years.  Unfortunately, there is no cure for MS, and the disease is fatal in a small percentage of cases.  Hope I have answered your query. Let me know if I can assist you further.

The most common course of the disease is the relapsing-remitting subtype, which is characterized by unpredictable acute attacks (relapses) followed by periods of relative remission. The other type, progressive subtype, is characterized by a steady functional decline from disease onset. MS patients frequently present with sensory loss, optic neuritis, weakness, and other neurologic deficits. The diagnosis is based on the patient's clinical history and examination in conjunction with magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and examination of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). PMC-llama13b_answer_original: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle weakness and wasting. It is the most common and most severe form of muscular dystrophy.  The disease is caused by an absence of dystrophin, a protein that helps keep muscle cells intact. Symptoms usually appear before age 6 and include difficulty walking, a waddling gait, and calf muscle weakness. The disease slowly progresses so that a person with Duchenne muscular dystrophy may eventually have difficulty getting up from a chair, climbing stairs, or walking.  Duchenne muscular dystrophy is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern. Symptoms are caused by a mutation in the DMD gene, which provides instructions for making the dystrophin protein. The mutation that causes Duchenne muscular dystrophy most often results from an deletion (removal) of a small section of the DMD gene.  Duchenne muscular dystrophy is usually diagnosed before age 6, when symptoms become apparent. Diagnosis may be confirmed by a blood test that measures the level of dystrophin in the blood or by a muscle biopsy.  Duchenne muscular dystrophy is managed with a combination of medications and physical therapy. Steroids and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) may be used to slow the progression of muscle weakness.  Duchenne muscular dystrophy is a genetic disorder. There is no known way to prevent the disease.  The prognosis for people with Duchenne muscular dystrophy is generally poor. Most people with the disease die in their early twenties due to respiratory failure or heart failure.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is an inherited disorder that involves progressive muscle weakness. These symptoms include difficulty walking, frequent falls, toe walking, and the inability to get up from a lying position. The symptoms progress until the person is confined to a wheelchair, which usually occurs by age 12.  Support groups, financial assistance, and educational resources are available.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is an inherited genetic disorder. It is caused by a mutation in the DMD gene. This gene is responsible for making a protein called dystrophin. This protein is important for the normal function of muscles.  Duchenne muscular dystrophy is an X-linked recessive disorder. This means that the gene responsible for the disorder is located on the X chromosome. Males have only one X chromosome. Females have two X chromosomes. In females who carry the mutated gene, it is usually the second copy of the gene that is mutated. Females who carry the mutated gene are rarely affected by Duchenne muscular dystrophy.  The symptoms of Duchenne muscular dystrophy usually appear before age 5. They include:  - Loss of muscle strength  - Frequent falls  - Trouble getting up from a lying or sitting position  - Walking and running problems  - Leg and calf muscle swelling  - Enlarged belly from breathing muscle weakness  - Problems eating and using utensils  - Learning disabilities  - Delayed speech   Physical exam  - While examining your child, the doctor will note how your child moves and interacts with others.  - The doctor will also check your child's muscle strength and reflexes.  - The doctor will use a device called a dynamometer to measure strength.  - The doctor will also check your child's ability to move the eyes and perform certain tasks.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle weakness. It is one of nine types of muscular dystrophy. Symptoms usually appear before age 6 and include difficulty walking, frequent falls, and an inability to keep the back straight. The disease slowly worsens until most victims are unable to walk by age 12. Duchenne muscular dystrophy is typically not diagnosed until age 3 or 4, when the disease has already caused muscle weakness and wasting. There is no known cure for Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Treatment involves exercise, braces, and wheelchairs.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Introduction: Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a common gastrointestinal disorder with a high prevalence rate and significant impact on quality of life. Previous studies have suggested a possible association between IBS and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). However, the nature of this association remains unclear. 2. Objectives: To investigate the association between IBS and PTSD and to explore the characteristics of IBS patients with PTSD. Methods: We performed a systematic review of the literature by searching PubMed, Embase, and Cochrane Library databases for relevant articles published between January 1990 and June 2017. 3. Results:Our results suggest that the association between IBS and PTSD is bidirectional. The prevalence of PTSD in IBS patients is higher than that in the general population. PTSD is associated with a younger age at IBS onset, a longer duration of IBS symptoms, and a higher prevalence of comorbid psychiatric disorders, particularly major depressive disorder. 4. Conclusions:PTSD is associated with IBS, and IBS patients have a higher prevalence of PTSD. Further studies are needed to investigate the mechanism underlying this association.

Symptoms may include disturbing thoughts, feelings, or dreams related to the events, mental or physical distress to trauma-related cues, attempts to avoid trauma-related cues, alterations in how a person thinks and feels, and an increase in the fight-or-flight response. These symptoms last for more than a month after the event. Young children are less likely to show distress, but instead may express their memories through play.

Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a common gastrointestinal disorder characterized by abdominal pain and altered bowel habits in the absence of detectable structural abnormalities. 2. Symptoms may include disturbing thoughts, feelings, or dreams related to the events, mental or physical distress to trauma-related cues, attempts to avoid trauma-related cues, alterations in how a person thinks and feels, and an increase in the fight-or-flight response. 3. The comorbidity of IBS and PTSD has been investigated in several studies. The results of these studies have been conflicting. Some studies have found an increased prevalence of PTSD in IBS patients compared to the general population, while others have not. Similarly, some studies have found an increased prevalence of IBS in PTSD patients, while others have not. 4. The aim of this paper was to perform a systematic review of the literature investigating the comorbidity of IBS and PTSD in order to clarify this area. We performed a systematic review of the literature using PubMed, EMBASE, and PsycINFO. We included all studies that investigated the comorbidity of IBS and PTSD, regardless of study design. Our search identified 25 studies that met our inclusion criteria. The results of these studies suggest that there is an increased prevalence of PTSD in IBS patients compared to the general population, while there is some evidence to suggest that there is an increased prevalence of IBS in PTSD patients. Further research in this area is required.

Keloids may be treated with corticosteroid injections, laser treatments, cryotherapy, and radiation therapy. 5. The best treatment for keloids is to prevent them from forming.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. Silicone gel or patches. 2. Corticosteroid injections. 3. Freezing tissue (cryotherapy). 4. Laser treatments. 5. Radiation. 6. Excision (removing the keloid). 7. Intralesional corticosteroid injections. 8. Interferon injections. 9. Topical retinoids. 10. Pressure
PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 1. Silicone gel or patches: These are the most commonly used treatments for keloids. They flatten the raised part of the scar and fade the redness of the keloid. They work best on younger scars (less than a year old). 2. Corticosteroid injections: These are injections of a steroid medication (such as triamcinolone) into the keloid. This can soften and flatten the keloid and make it less red. Corticosteroid injections work best on smaller keloids (less than 2 cm across). 3. Freezing (cryotherapy): This treatment freezes the keloid using liquid nitrogen. It can flatten the keloid and make it less red. Cryotherapy works best on smaller keloids (less than 2 cm across). 4. Laser treatments: This treatment uses a laser to flatten the keloid and fade the redness. It works best on older (more than a year old) keloids. 5. Surgery: Surgery to remove the keloid (excision) is usually only considered if other treatments don't work, or if the keloid is very large. Sometimes, surgery is combined with other treatments. For example, surgery may be used to remove the raised part of the keloid, and then a silicone patch is used to flatten the rest of the scar.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1. Keloids are a type of abnormal scar tissue that forms as a result of excess collagen production during the healing process. 2. There is no cure for keloids, but some topical treatments may help reduce the size of the scar. 3. Corticosteroid injections and laser treatments may also help reduce the size of keloids. 4. Surgical removal of large keloids may be necessary.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Pancreatic cancer is one of the most aggressive malignancies, with a 5-year survival rate of only 5%.2. Surgical resection is the best treatment for pancreatic cancer but only 15-20% of patients are candidates for surgery because of late diagnosis, metastatic disease, or inadequate pancreatic tissue to allow for complete surgical resection.3. For those patients in whom surgical resection is not feasible, the treatment of pancreatic cancer is palliative, focusing on pain control and surgical or radiologic biliary decompression.4. Palliative treatment is aimed at relieving the pain and suffering associated with this disease and improving quality of life.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. Pancreatic cancer is very difficult to treat and often has a poor prognosis. 2. Clinical trials are another treatment option. 4. A team of specialists will help determine the best treatment plan for your father. 5. You and your father should discuss his treatment options with his doctor.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 1. Alternative solutions for pancreatic cancer are limited. 2. Certain herbs and supplements, such as mistletoe, lycopene, and selenium, may help prevent pancreatic cancer or reduce the risk of developing it, but more research is needed to determine their effectiveness. 4. Avoiding tobacco and alcohol may help prevent some cases of pancreatic cancer.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. Pancreatic cancer is very difficult to treat and has a poor prognosis. 2. Surgery is the best option for a chance of cure. 3. PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 1. Pancreatic cancer is one of the most aggressive malignancies with poor prognosis.2. The only curative treatment is surgical resection.3. In advanced cases, the only treatment option is palliative care.4. Palliative care includes pain management, nutritional support, and other supportive measures.5. Systemic chemotherapy is the mainstay of treatment in advanced cases.6. Gemcitabine is the standard first-line treatment for patients with metastatic pancreatic cancer.7. Other drugs like 5-FU, oxaliplatin, irinotecan, and Abraxane can be used as well.8. Newer drugs like FOLFIRINOX (a combination of 5-FU, irinotecan, and oxaliplatin) show promising results with median survival of 11 months and progression free survival of 5.5 months.9. Targeted therapies like erlotinib and rituximab have shown modest benefits.10. Palliative radiotherapy can be used for symptom control.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1. Pancreatic cancer is one of the most aggressive malignancies with a very poor prognosis. 2. The only chance of cure is surgical resection of the tumor. However, only 15-20% of patients are eligible for surgical resection at the time of diagnosis. 3. The mainstay of treatment for locally advanced or metastatic disease is chemotherapy. Gemcitabine is the standard of care for patients with metastatic disease. 4. In patients with locally advanced disease, combined radiation and chemotherapy are recommended. 5. In patients with metastatic disease, the combination of 5-FU and oxaliplatin is recommended. 6. In patients with locally advanced inoperable disease, the combination of 5-FU and external beam radiation is recommended.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Osteoporosis is a disease that thins and weakens the bones to the point that they become fragile and break easily. Women and men with osteoporosis most often break bones in the hip, spine, and wrist, but any bone can be affected. 2. Although osteoporosis can strike at any age, it is most common among older people, especially older women. 3. As many as half of all women and a quarter of men older than 50 will break a bone due to osteoporosis. 4. Osteoporosis is a silent disease. Bones lose mass without causing pain until a fracture occurs. 5. Although osteoporosis can't be cured, there are treatments that can help keep bones strong and reduce the risk of breaking a bone.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: Certain factors can increase your risk of developing osteoporosis. These include:  -  Being a white or Asian woman.  -  Having a small, thin body frame.  -  Having a family history of osteoporosis.  -  Having osteopenia (low bone density).  -  Having certain medical problems, such as rheumatoid arthritis or thyroid problems.  -  Taking certain medicines, such as steroids.  -  Having a high amount of alcohol use.  -  Being a smoker.  -  Having a sedentary lifestyle.  -  Having a diet low in calcium and vitamin D.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. Osteoporosis is a disease that thins and weakens the bones to the point that they become fragile and break easily. PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Sheehan's syndrome is a rare complication of severe postpartum hemorrhage that leads to pituitary gland failure. 2. The pituitary gland is responsible for producing hormones that regulate many body functions. 3. Sheehan's syndrome occurs when the pituitary gland does not make enough hormones. 4. The most common symptom is failure to make milk (lactation failure). 5. Other symptoms may include failure to have normal growth and development, low blood pressure, depression, weight gain, and inability to have children (infertility). 6. The diagnosis is made by measuring hormone levels in the blood. 7. Treatment involves taking hormones to replace the hormones that the body is not making.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. Sheehan's syndrome is a condition that occurs when the pituitary gland does not produce enough hormones due to damage or loss of blood supply. 2. The pituitary gland controls the release of hormones from the thyroid, adrenal, and ovaries. 3. Damage to the pituitary can occur during childbirth (obstetric fistula). 4. During childbirth, the pituitary may be damaged due to loss of blood supply. 5. This can cause hormone deficiencies. 6. In some cases, the pituitary may also be damaged by tumors, infections, or injury. 7. The symptoms of Sheehan's syndrome vary depending on the hormone that is lacking. 8. Symptoms may include fatigue, depression, lack of menstrual periods, low blood pressure, and low body temperature. 9. The diagnosis is made by measuring hormone levels in the blood. 10. Treatment depends on the hormone that is lacking.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 1. Sheehan's syndrome is a rare complication of postpartum hemorrhage, wherein the pituitary gland is damaged, resulting in failure of the body to produce adequate quantities of thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH), growth hormone (GH), prolactin, and often adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). 2. The pituitary gland is extremely sensitive to ischemic injury, and blood loss during delivery can result in pituitary damage. 3. Sheehan's syndrome is characterized by failure of lactation, amenorrhea (absence of menstruation), and failure to resume normal body contour and hair distribution after delivery. 4. Patients may also present with failure to thrive, lethargy, and signs of hypopituitarism. 5. Diagnosis is based on clinical suspicion, and hormonal levels of TSH, GH, prolactin, and cortisol may be measured to confirm the diagnosis. 6. Treatment is supportive and consists of hormone replacement therapy.

Damage to the pituitary gland can lead to hormonal imbalances, including low thyroid hormone levels (hypothyroidism), low adrenal hormone levels (Addison's disease), and low estrogen levels (menopause). 4. Diagnosis of Sheehan's syndrome is based on a woman's medical history and physical examination. 5. Common symptoms include fatigue, low energy, low body temperature, constipation, and dry skin. 6. Treatment involves hormone replacement therapy.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 1. Sheehan's syndrome is a condition that occurs due to reduced blood flow to the pituitary gland, resulting in reduced hormone production. 2. The pituitary gland produces hormones that control the release of other hormones from the thyroid, adrenal glands, and ovaries. 3. In Sheehan's syndrome, the pituitary gland does not produce enough of these hormones, which can lead to problems with growth and development in children and problems with the menstrual cycle and infertility in women. 4. Diagnosis is based on symptoms, medical history, physical examination, and blood tests. 5. Treatment may include hormone replacement therapy and medications to stimulate the pituitary gland to make more hormones.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1. Sheehan's syndrome is a rare condition that occurs due to severe bleeding after delivery causing pituitary gland failure. 2. Diagnosis is based on symptoms, blood tests, and imaging tests. 5. Treatment involves hormone replacement therapy.

What are the symptoms of an inguinal hernia?  The main symptom is a bulge or swelling in the groin or scrotal area. It may appear when standing and straining and disappear when lying down. It may be possible to push the hernia back into the abdomen. 4. How is an inguinal hernia diagnosed?  The diagnosis is made by physical examination. A medical history will be taken and a physical examination of the abdomen will be performed. 5. How is an inguinal hernia treated?  If the hernia is painful, and the intestines may be stuck in the hernia, it should be reduced (pushed back into the abdomen). If the hernia cannot be reduced, surgery is usually needed. If the hernia is painless, surgery is still the best option. Surgery is the only way to be sure that the hernia will not become worse. 6. What are the risks of an inguinal hernia?  The main risk is that the intestines may become stuck in the hernia. This can cause obstruction, which is a blockage of the intestines. The intestines can then become twisted and cut off from their blood supply. This is a medical emergency.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. The U.S. National Institutes of Health's Web site, MEDLINEplus, provides consumer information about PTSD and its treatment. 2. The National Library of Medicine's PubMed database was searched for PTSD treatment outcome articles published in 2001 and 2002. The search was limited to English language articles, reviews, and journal articles. The search was further limited to articles about treatment outcome. A total of 115 citations were found. 3. The articles were evaluated for inclusion according to the following criteria: sample size of at least 10 participants, random assignment to treatment conditions, use of standardized assessments for PTSD, and presentation of sufficient information to calculate an effect size. A total of 29 articles met the inclusion criteria. 4. The articles were summarized, and the treatment outcome data were extracted and tabulated. The treatment outcome data were then converted to standardized effect sizes. This report focuses on the treatment of PTSD in adults. 5. The review of the literature indicates that cognitive behavioral treatments are the most effective in the treatment of PTSD. The evidence is particularly strong for cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and exposure therapy. Other promising treatments include eye movement desensitization and reprocessing (EMDR), supportive counseling, and psychopharmacological treatments. 6. The review of the literature also indicates that there are a number of effective treatments for PTSD. It is important to note that most of the studies reviewed were conducted with small samples and were not always well-controlled. More research is needed to determine which treatments work best for specific subpopulations (e.g., children, combat veterans) and comorbid conditions (e.g., major depressive disorder, substance abuse).

Adenocarcinoma begins in the cells that line the inside of the lower part of the esophagus and is most common in the lower part of the esophagus.

c. Eating too much junk food 
d. Not getting enough physical activity 
e. Spending too much time watching TV or playing video games 
f. Genetics 
g. Environmental factors such as the accessibility of food and the types of foods available 
h. Psychological factors such as stress and depression 
i. Other medical conditions or medications 
2. A junk food tax could be effective in reducing obesity rates if the money collected was used for obesity prevention programs. 
3. Preventing obesity involves encouraging healthy eating habits in children, providing easy access to healthy foods and physical activities, and teaching people how to balance the number of calories they eat with the number of calories they burn.

a. Weight loss 
b. Increased energy and stamina 
c. Improved sleep 
d. Stronger bones and muscles 
e. Lower risk of heart disease, diabetes, and some cancers 
f. Improved mental health 
g. Lower risk of depression and anxiety 
h. Better self-esteem 
i. Improved social life

Glaucoma is a group of diseases that can damage the eye's optic nerve and result in vision loss and blindness. The most common form of the disease is open-angle glaucoma. With early treatment, you can often protect your eyes against serious vision loss.  What causes glaucoma?  In open-angle glaucoma, fluid pressure inside the eyes slowly increases over time. Often there are no symptoms at first. Without treatment, the eye pressure will eventually cause damage to the optic nerve and may result in vision loss.  In closed-angle glaucoma, also called narrow-angle glaucoma, the fluid pressure in the eye suddenly increases. This can happen for a short time in some people with open-angle glaucoma, but it is more common in people with closed-angle glaucoma. Closed-angle glaucoma is an emergency because it can cause blindness in just a few days.  How is glaucoma diagnosed?  Your eye care professional will diagnose glaucoma with a comprehensive eye exam. This exam will include testing your visual acuity (sharpness), checking your refractive error, and measuring your intraocular pressure (IOP).  The IOP test is usually performed with an instrument called a tonometer.  What are the treatments for glaucoma?  The most common treatment for open-angle glaucoma is prescription eyedrops. These eyedrops lower the pressure in the eye by either reducing the amount of fluid produced or by increasing the drainage of fluid from the eye.  For closed-angle glaucoma, the immediate treatment is usually a laser surgery called iridotomy. This surgery creates a small hole in the iris, which allows the fluid pressure in the eye to balance and prevents further damage.  How can I prevent glaucoma?  You can help

Over time, straight-ahead vision may decrease until no vision remains. 4. The second form of glaucoma is narrow-angle glaucoma. With narrow-angle glaucoma, the fluid pressure in the eye suddenly increases. This can happen for a short time, or it can last for days. It can occur from time to time or it can happen regularly. With narrow-angle glaucoma, there is a sudden pain in the eye or a headache. There may be nausea, vomiting, and a red, swollen eye. The vision may become cloudy and then clear up, or it may remain clear. 5. The goal of glaucoma treatment is to lower the pressure inside the eye. The most common treatments are prescription eyedrops, laser treatments, and surgery.

This study evaluated the use of estrogen plus progestin (E + P) versus placebo in 47,000 postmenopausal women aged 50 to 79 years for 11 years. The study found an increased risk of invasive ovarian cancer in women taking E + P (213 cases, 2002-2003) compared with women taking placebo (176 cases, 2000-2001). The risk of ovarian cancer was also higher in women taking E + P who had a history of endometrial cancer (67 cases, 2002-2003) or hypertension (77 cases, 2000-2001) than in women with neither risk factor taking placebo (37 cases, 2000-2001). The risk of ovarian cancer was not increased in women taking E + P who had a history of coronary heart disease (115 cases, 2002-2003) or diabetes (94 cases, 2000-2001) compared with women taking placebo with these risk factors (104 cases, 2000-2001).

PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 1995 was a pivotal year for ovarian cancer research. In 1995, two landmark studies were published that would change the way ovarian cancer was treated. The first study, conducted by the Gynecologic Oncology Group (GOG), randomized 465 women with stage III and IV ovarian cancer to either cisplatin and paclitaxel chemotherapy or paclitaxel and carboplatin chemotherapy. This study showed that the combination of cisplatin and paclitaxel resulted in a statistically significant improvement in progression-free survival and overall survival compared to the other regimen. 1995 also saw the publication of the results of a study conducted by the National Surgical Adjuvant Breast and Bowel Project (NSABP). This study randomized 462 women with stage I and II ovarian cancer to either observation or adjuvant chemotherapy with the cyclical combination of cisplatin, cyclophosphamide, and doxorubicin. This study showed a statistically significant improvement in progression-free survival and overall survival in the group that received adjuvant chemotherapy. Patients receiving Suboxone tablets should be given a complete course of treatment of any associated opioid dependence, and must be monitored to ensure that they are complying with their treatment plan. Addiction to opioids is a chronic disease. Relapse to illicit drug use is a characteristic of addiction and is expected in the treatment of opioid-dependent individuals. Buprenorphine alone does not treat or prevent relapse to opioid abuse. These problems may be less likely to occur if blood pressure is controlled.    Guanfacine works by controlling the nerve impulses along certain nerve pathways. As a result, it relaxes the blood vessels so that blood passes through them more easily. This helps to lower blood pressure.    Guanfacine extended-release tablets are also used alone or together with other medicines to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) in children and adolescents. It works in the treatment of ADHD by increasing attention and decreasing restlessness in children and adults who are overactive, cannot concentrate for very long, or are easily distracted and impulsive. This medicine is used as part of a treatment program to control symptoms of ADHD. Treatment with guanfacine is usually limited to 3 months. PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 3-SCA3 3-Spinocerebellar ataxia type 3 3-Spinocerebellar ataxia type 3 is a degenerative disease of the nervous system that causes progressive problems with movement. People with SCA3 have difficulty with balance, coordination, and walking. Problems with speech and swallowing can also occur. People with SCA3 may experience other symptoms such as muscle cramps, twitching, or wasting (atrophy) of the muscles. Some people with SCA3 may also have problems with involuntary movements or muscle stiffness.  The disease usually begins in adulthood, usually between ages 30 and 40 years. People with SCA3 may also have problems with thinking and reasoning (cognitive skills). Some people with SCA3 may have psychiatric symptoms, such as depression or hallucinations.  The disease is caused by a mutation in a gene on chromosome 14. The gene carries instructions for making a protein called ataxin-3. Researchers think that the mutation causes ataxin-3 to fold incorrectly, and the misfolded protein cannot perform its normal function. The disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. People with one copy of the mutated gene have the disease. People with SCA3 inherit one copy of the mutated gene from one affected parent. When parents have one child with SCA3, there is a 50 percent chance of the next child being affected.  Referencce:

PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: Cold sores are caused by the herpes simplex virus type 1. Most people who have cold sores first notice them in childhood. They may get them frequently for years, and then the outbreaks begin to decrease.  Cold sores may be triggered by stress, illness, or sunburn. They may also be triggered by fever or a booster shot. There is no cure for cold sores. Medicines can help ease some of the symptoms. These include ointments that numb the blisters or antibiotics that control secondary bacterial infections.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: Cold sores are caused by the herpes simplex virus. They may appear on the mouth, lips, or throat and are very contagious.  You can help prevent the spread of cold sores by not kissing or sharing food while you have a cold sore.  Treatment may not be needed, as cold sores usually go away on their own in 7 to 10 days.  Over-the-counter creams or gels can help ease pain and discomfort.  Medicines that can be applied directly to the cold sore include:  - Antibacterial creams or ointments  - Antiviral creams or ointments  - Pain reliever creams or ointments  - Warm compresses  - Salt water gargles  - Avoid hot beverages, spicy foods, and acidic foods  - Wash your hands often to prevent spreading the virus to other parts of your body or to other people
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: Cold sores are caused by the herpes simplex virus type 1. This virus is contagious. You can reduce your chances of passing the virus to others by washing your hands frequently and not kissing or sharing food or utensils when you have a cold sore.  Cold sores usually go through stages, including:  - A prodrome (tender swelling of the skin before a sore appears).  - A small, raised, firm, painful, pink or red sore that quickly becomes yellow or white.  - A crusty lesion that slowly heals over 1 to 2 weeks.  You may have a prodrome, but you may not always have symptoms. A prodrome is a warning sign that a sore is about to appear. It is not fully developed, so it may not be noticed. Signs and symptoms of a prodrome include:  - Tingling, itching, or burning at the site before a sore appears.  - A small, firm swelling at the site before a sore appears.  - A cluster of small fluid-filled blisters that quickly become covered with a scab.  The prodrome phase may last 2 to 4 days, but it can last as long as 3 weeks. The sore can last 1 to 2 weeks.  You can treat cold sores by applying ice or a warm cloth to the sore. You can also apply a topical anesthetic to numb the pain. Do not smoke, because smoke can irritate the sore.  To reduce swelling and discomfort, you can take an over-the-counter pain reliever, such as acetaminophen, ibuprofen, or aspirin.  You can use a topical antiviral cream, such as acyclovir, penciclovir, or docosanol, to help reduce the spread of the virus and shorten the healing time.  If you get a cold sore often, you can take an oral antiviral medication, such as acyclovir, famciclovir, or valacyclovir. These medications can help reduce the frequency of cold sores.  If you have a weakened immune system, you may need to take antiviral medication to prevent cold sores.  Cold s
