PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: Cold sores are caused by the herpes simplex virus, which is usually spread by direct contact with an infected person.  There is no cure for cold sores, but you can lessen the symptoms and reduce the spread of the virus with these self-care tips:  - Wash your hands frequently with soap and water, especially before meals and after touching a cold sore.  - Avoid close contact with others when your cold sores are active.  - Try not to touch your mouth or nose.  - Use your own toothbrush, drinking glass, and eating utensils.  - Avoid hot, spicy, acidic, and salty foods. These foods can irritate the tissue around the sore and may slow healing.  - Use an over-the-counter pain reliever, such as acetaminophen, ibuprofen, or aspirin.  - You can apply a warm, wet compress to the sore for 10 to 15 minutes several times a day.  - You can apply a lip balm that contains sunscreen.  - Try to avoid irritants and things that may trigger a cold sore, such as stress, sun exposure, and dental procedures.  - Get enough sleep and eat a healthy diet.  - Try to manage stress.  - If you have a weakened immune system, check with your health care provider about getting a prescription for an antiviral medication. This may help reduce the number of cold sores.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. The treatment of HIV infection is constantly evolving. New guidelines are issued by the Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS) as soon as there is sufficient evidence to support a change in practice. The most uptodate HIV treatment guidelines can be found at the DHHS website (http://aidsinfo.nih.gov/guidelines) and at the website of the Johns Hopkins HIV Guide lines (http://www.hopkins-hivguide.org/Hopkins-HIV-Guide-Lines.html). 2. The current standard of care for HIV infection involves the use of combination antiretroviral therapy (cART). The typical cART regimen consists of two nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) plus either a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI), a protease inhibitor (PI), or an integrase inhibitor. 3. The choice of which drugs to use initially in a given patient is based on several factors, including the patient's HIV viral load and CD4 count, the presence of any co-morbid conditions, and the potential for particular drugs to interact with each other as well as with other medications the patient may be taking. 4. In general, the goal of initial therapy is to reduce the patient's viral load to <50 copies/mL and to increase the CD4 count to >350 cells/mL. 5. The most common side effects of NRTIs include nausea, headache, dizziness, fatigue, and lipodystrophy. Lipodystrophy may be associated with an increased risk of developing insulin resistance and metabolic syndrome. 6. NNRTIs are generally well tolerated by most patients. The most common side effect of NNRTIs is rash, which usually resolves after a few weeks of therapy. 7. PIs are associated with several side effects, including nausea, diarrhea, headache, fatigue, and lipodystrophy. In addition, PIs may interact with some common medications, including certain antibiotics (such as erythromycin), anticonvulsants (such as ph
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1) Antiretroviral therapy (ART) should be initiated as soon as possible after HIV diagnosis, regardless of CD4 count or symptoms. 2) The goal of treatment is to reduce HIV viral load to <50 copies/mL. 3) The preferred initial regimen is two nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) + an integrase strand transfer inhibitor (INSTI) or a protease inhibitor (PI) + a NRTI. 4) The preferred alternative regimen is two NRTIs + a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) + a NRTI. 5) The preferred and alternative regimens should be used in combination with a pharmacological booster (e.g., ritonavir or cobicistat) for the PI or NNRTI, as needed, to achieve adequate drug levels. 6) The preferred and alternative regimens should include a fixed-dose combination product whenever possible. 7) All regimens should include at least one NRTI with demonstrated activity against HIV-2. 8) All regimens should include a drug with demonstrated activity against HBV. 9) All persons initiating ART should be offered a preventive therapy for HIV-associated opportunistic infections, such as Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) prophylaxis. 10) All persons initiating ART should be offered a complete screening for sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and treatment for any identified infections. 11) All persons initiating ART should be offered a complete physical examination, including evaluation for oropharyngeal candidiasis, and a complete set of laboratory tests, including complete blood count (CBC), basic chemistry panel, liver function tests (LFTs), renal function tests (RFTs), and HIV viral load. 12) All persons initiating ART should be educated about adherence, medication side effects, and the importance of regular follow-up visits. 13) All persons initiating ART should receive a written treatment plan that includes information on adherence, side effects, and what to do if a
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 1) HIV-positive trans women should be started on ART as soon as possible, regardless of CD4 count or clinical symptoms. 2) The preferred first-line regimen for most patients is a two-drug regimen containing either lamivudine or emtricitabine + either tenofovir or abacavir. 3) The preferred third drug is either a boosted-protease inhibitor or a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor. 4) The most important thing is to start treatment as soon as possible, because HIV will inevitably progress to AIDS if left untreated. 5) Treatment adherence is extremely important, so the regimen should be one that the patient can easily remember and follow. 6) Regular follow-up visits with the treating physician are also very important, so that any problems or side effects can be dealt with before they become serious. 7) The most important side effect to look out for is lipodystrophy, which can be minimized by using a regimen containing a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor. 8) If the patient has a history of injection drug use, they should be referred to a substance abuse treatment program, because this greatly increases the risk of HIV progression. 9) If the patient is also sexually active with men, they should be counseled on how to prevent transmission to their partners. 10) The most important thing is to get the patient into care as soon as possible, and to make sure they are able to adhere to the treatment regimen.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. HIV positive patients should be started on antiretroviral therapy (ART) as soon as possible after diagnosis, regardless of CD4 count or clinical symptoms. 2. The goals of ART are to: a. Reduce the viral load to undetectable levels b. Improve immune function c. Reduce the risk of opportunistic infections and other complications of HIV infection 3. Current guidelines recommend starting with two nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) plus an integrase inhibitor, a protease inhibitor, or a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI). 4. The choice of which specific drugs to use within each class depends on several factors, including the patient's HIV subtype, the presence of any resistance-inducing mutations, and the patient's previous treatment history. 5. The most common side effects from ART are gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. 6. Lipid abnormalities are also common side effects of some ARVs, especially the protease inhibitors. 7. The most serious complications of ART are hepatotoxicity and the development of a syndrome known as lipodystrophy, which is characterized by abdominal fat accumulation, breast enlargement, and altered cholesterol levels. 8. The most commonly used prophylactic regimens are trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and fluconazole. 9. The most common side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is a diffuse maculopapular rash that occurs in approximately 10% of patients. 10. The most common side effect of fluconazole is nausea. 11. Both medications are generally well tolerated by most patients. 12. Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole are the two most commonly used prophylactic agents for PCP. 13. The most common side effect of IVIG is a headache. 14. PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 1) Treatment as prevention: One of the most exciting developments in HIV care and treatment is the concept of treatment as prevention. This means that if someone is on antiretroviral therapy (ART) and has an undetectable viral load, they cannot transmit the virus to their sexual partner. This is a huge motivator for people to start and stay in treatment. 2) ART is a lifelong commitment: People need to understand that once they start ART, they are going to be on it for life. It is a commitment that they need to be ready for. 3) ART is not a cure: People need to understand that ART is not a cure for HIV. It is a management tool that helps people live with the virus. 4) Side effects: People need to be aware of potential side effects of ART and know how to manage them. 5) Adherence: Adherence is key to successful treatment. People need to understand the importance of taking their medication every day.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Shingles is caused by the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus (VZV) which causes chickenpox. 2. Shingles is characterized by a painful, blistering rash, usually on the face or body. 3. The virus that causes shingles can spread from a person with active shingles to another person who has never had chickenpox. 4. Once infected, the person will develop chickenpox, however, they will not develop shingles. 5. A person with active shingles can spread the virus when the rash is in the blister-phase. The virus is less often spread after the rash has developed crusts. 6. The period of time during which the virus may be spread is usually about 1-2 days before the rash appears and about 4-5 days after the rash has appeared. 7. Shingles is not contagious if the rash has crusted over. 8. Shingles is treated with antiviral medications (Acyclovir, Valacyclovir, Famciclovir) which may prevent complications of shingles, and reduce the severity and duration of symptoms. 9. Shingles is most common in people over age 60. It is less common in children.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. You have not mentioned your age.2. Sleep apnea is a condition in which you have repeated episodes of stopping breathing during sleep.3. It is due to obstruction of the airway at the back of the throat.4. The treatment is a CPAP machine.5. It is a device that delivers air under pressure to keep the airway open.6. It takes about 2 weeks to get used to it.7. Once you get used to it, you will be able to sleep comfortably.8. It will take around 2 months for the swelling to reduce.9. You should also lose weight and avoid alcohol and sedatives.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. Sleep apnea is a sleep disorder characterized by pauses in breathing during sleep. Each episode, called an apnea, lasts long enough so that one or more breaths are missed, and such episodes occur repeatedly throughout the night. 2. Central sleep apnea is a disorder that involves a pause in breathing while sleeping. It occurs when the brain fails to send proper signals to the breathing muscles. 3. Obstructive sleep apnea is a sleep disorder in which breathing repeatedly stops and stas. If you snore loudly and feel tired even after a full night's sleep, you might have sleep apnea. 4. In central sleep apnea, the muscles that control breathing aren't working properly. This causes breathing to stop and start. Central sleep apnea may occur as a result of a stroke, brain injury or infection. 5. In obstructive sleep apnea, the muscles that control breathing are working, but the airway is blocked. The blockage may be caused by extra tissue around the airway, enlarged tonsils or adenoids, or other conditions. 6. Treatment for sleep apnea depends on the cause of the disorder. If you have sleep apnea, you may need a medical device to help you breathe at night. One such device is a continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) machine. 7. A CPAP machine uses a mask to deliver air under pressure to your upper airway. The pressure keeps your airway open so you can breathe while you sleep. 8. You'll probably need to use a CPAP machine every night to help you breathe. It will make you feel more rested and alert during the day. 9. If you use a CPAP machine, you'll need to clean the mask and tubing every day. Be sure to follow the manufacturer's instructions carefully. 10. If you're using a CPAP machine and you develop symptoms such as shortness of breath, chest pain or a fast heartbeat, call your doctor right away.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 1. You have not mentioned your age which is very important in case of swelling.2. Sleep apnea is itself a risk factor for swelling.3. CPAP will help to overcome the obstruction and help you to get good sleep.5. You should also do following to get rid of swelling:a. Avoid standing for long time.b. Keep your limbs elevated while sleeping.c. Avoid salty food.d. Use less salt in your diet.e. Do regular exercise.f. Lose weight if you are obese.g. Quit alcohol and smoking.h. Wear compression stockings.i. Keep your body warm.j. Avoid long sitting.k. Elevate your head while sleeping.6. If swelling still persists then you should consult with your physician.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 1. Sleep apnea is a potentially serious sleep disorder in which breathing repeatedly stops and stas. If you snore loudly and feel tired even after a full night's sleep, you might have sleep apnea. 2. Sleep apnea is a common disorder. More than 1 in 4 adults have at least mild sleep apnea. 3. The main types of sleep apnea are: Obstructive sleep apnea, which is the more common form that occurs when throat muscles relax Central sleep apnea, which occurs when your brain doesn't send proper signals to the muscles that control breathing Complex sleep apnea syndrome, also known as treatment-emergent central sleep apnea, which occurs when someone has both obstructive sleep apnea and central sleep apnea 4. Sleep apnea is often more severe if you are overweight. Even a 10 percent weight loss can help reduce symptoms. 5. Treatments include weight loss, continuous positive airway pressure, and surgery.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: 1. The amount of fluid retention caused by sleep apnea can vary greatly from person to person. 2. The amount of fluid that is removed with CPAP is highly variable and depends on the severity of the sleep apnea and the underlying cause of the fluid retention. 3. In general, people with severe sleep apnea and significant fluid retention may have the majority of their fluid removed with CPAP within the first week or two of use. 4. People with mild sleep apnea and fluid retention may not notice any significant change in fluid retention for several weeks to months.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 1. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is a type of cancer in which the bone marrow makes too many lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell). CLL is a slow-growing blood and bone marrow disease that usually occurs during or after middle age. 2. The most common symptoms are fatigue and enlarged lymph nodes. Other symptoms include fever, night sweats, weight loss, and swelling in the neck, armpits, or groin. 3. The diagnosis is based on blood and bone marrow tests. There is no cure, but medicines may help control the symptoms. People may live for many years with CLL.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: 67. (Ref: Nelson 18th ed chapter 351) Jaundice is common in newborns. It is usually a benign condition called physiologic jaundice. It occurs during the first week of life and is due to the immaturity of the newborn liver. It can be recognized by the yellowing of the sclera and the presence of other signs of liver dysfunction, such as poor feeding, lethargy, and irritability. The serum bilirubin level is usually less than 10 mg/dL and the direct component accounts for less than 20% of the total serum bilirubin. The jaundice usually begins on the face and moves down to the trunk and extremities. It is rare for jaundice to be present in the first 24 hours of life. If jaundice is present at this time, the child should be evaluated for hemolytic anemia, galactosemia, and sepsis.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 1. Jaundice is common in newborns because their liver is not yet fully developed. However, jaundice can occur at any age and may indicate a serious illness. 2. Jaundice is a yellowish staining of the skin and whites of the eyes. It is caused by high levels of bilirubin in the blood. Bilirubin comes from the breakdown of red blood cells. 3. Jaundice may be a sign of a problem with the liver, bile ducts, or red blood cells. It can occur with many different disorders, including: 4. Viral hepatitis 5. Biliary atresia 6. Physiologic jaundice 7. Gilbert's syndrome 8. Breast milk jaundice 9. Sepsis 10. Liver cancer 11. Other liver disorders 12. Hemolytic anemia

PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: Yes, large, inoperable schwannomas can be treated with radiation therapy or chemotherapy.  Radiation therapy has been used for many years to treat large, inoperable schwannomas.  It is thought that radiation may take years to shrink a tumor.  In some cases, the tumor will stop growing, but it will not shrink.  In other cases, the tumor will shrink after radiation treatment.  The goal of radiation therapy is to shrink the tumor so that it can be surgically removed.  Chemotherapy has also been used to treat large, inoperable schwannomas.  A recent study showed that 40% of patients treated with a combination of carboplatin and vincristine had a partial or complete response to treatment.  Partial or complete responses occurred in 58% of patients treated with a combination of carboplatin and paclitaxel.  Partial or complete responses occurred in 29% of patients treated with a combination of carboplatin and gemcitabine.  The goal of chemotherapy is to shrink the tumor so that it can be surgically removed.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: 5-Etretinate is an oral medication that has been used in the past with some success. However, the side effects of this medication (severe skin rashes, bony decalcification) have limited its use. More recently, the oral alkylating agent busulfan has been used with some success. In addition, several investigators have reported successful treatment of large and/or recurrent schwannomas with the biological agent octreotide. Octreotide is a synthetic analog of somatostatin that when given subcutaneously or by monthly intravenous infusion, produces sustained tumor shrinkage in approximately 50% of patients. The treatment is usually well tolerated, and the tumor shrinkage can be dramatic.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) plus radiotherapy is an effective treatment for large, inoperable schwannomas.

PMC-llama13b_answer_v3: Familial Mediterranean Fever (FMF) is a condition characterized by recurrent episodes of fever and serositis (inflammation of serous membranes, including peritoneum, pleura, and synovial membranes). It is an autosomal recessive disease that most commonly affects individuals of Armenian, Sephardic Jewish, and Arabic origins. The gene for familial Mediterranean fever is called pyrin (for its relation to fever) and encodes for a protein called marenostrin (for its relation to serositis). Marenostrin is expressed in neutrophils, and it is believed that it regulates the function of neutrophils. FMF is characterized by attacks of fever accompanied by any combination of the following: serositis (inflammation of serous membranes), synovitis (inflammation of the joints), and/or peritonitis (inflammation of the peritoneum). The attacks are typically accompanied by extreme fatigue and malaise. Attacks usually last 1-3 days and tend to recur at irregular intervals, with a tendency to cluster. The attacks are generally shorter and less severe with advancing age. In children, the first attack is usually severe and requires hospitalization.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: Familial Mediterranean Fever is an inherited disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of fever and serositis (inflammation of serous membranes, including peritoneum, pleura, and synovial membranes). The condition is common in the Mediterranean area, but other ethnic groups may also be affected. The gene responsible for familial Mediterranean fever is called pyrin (for its relation to fever) and is located on the short arm of chromosome 16.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v5: 1. Familial Mediterranean fever (FMF) is a condition characterized by recurrent episodes of fever and serositis (inflammation of serous membranes, including peritoneum, pleura, and synovial membranes). 2. The first attack generally occurs in childhood or the teens and is characterized by fever, abdominal pain, and pleuritic pain, with or without peritoneal or joint inflammation. 3. Subsequent attacks are usually shorter and less severe and may only involve fever and abdominal pain. 4. Between attacks, patients are usually well and have no signs or symptoms of disease. 5. Attacks can be triggered by physical exertion, emotional stress, or infection. 6. After an attack, patients usually have a moderate degree of tenderness in the abdomen and sometimes in the pleural or synovial areas. 7. The attacks generally last 1-3 days, and patients are fully recovered 1-2 weeks after an attack. 8. In patients with FMF, the risk of amyloidosis is increased. Amyloid deposits are found in the abdominal fat pad and in the synovium of affected joints. 9. In rare patients, end-stage renal disease may develop. 10. The most common laboratory finding is a moderate leukocytosis during an attack. 11. Serum levels of SAA (serum amyloid A) are increased during attacks. 12. There is no specific treatment for FMF. 13. Patients with FMF should avoid exercising or engaging in activities that result in sweating just before an attack. 14. Colchicine is effective in preventing attacks of FMF. 15. Patients with FMF should be educated about the signs and symptoms of amyloidosis so that they can report them to their physicians.

If the condition is due to a medication side effect, the medication would be adjusted or discontinued.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: Hi, Welcome to PMC-LLaMA. Lupus is a chronic disease that can affect any part of the body, but usually involves the skin, joints, kidneys, blood cells, heart and lungs. It is an autoimmune disease, which means that the body's immune system attacks the tissues and organs. Lupus is treated with steroids and immunosuppressants.  Steroids are used to treat inflammation and suppress the immune system. They are the mainstay of treatment for lupus. Steroids can be taken by mouth, as creams or ointments, or intravenously.  Immunosuppressants are medicines that suppress the immune system. They are used to treat severe lupus. Examples of immunosuppressants include azathioprine, cyclophosphamide, methotrexate, and mycophenolate mofetil.  I hope this will help you. Best wishes, Mehrnaz
PMC-llama13b_answer_v1: Lupus is a chronic disease that can affect different organs and tissues in the body. It can affect the skin, joints, kidneys, blood cells, heart and lungs, and brain. There are many kinds of lupus. The most common type, systemic lupus erythematosus, is a chronic disease that can be mild to life-threatening. Another type is acute cutaneous lupus, which is a mild form that mostly affects the skin. Neonatal lupus, which is rare, affects newborns.  Anyone can get lupus, but women are most at risk. Lupus is also more common in African American, Hispanic, Asian, and Native American women than in Caucasian women. The cause of lupus is not known. Genetics and environmental factors may play a role. Lupus has many symptoms. Some common ones are joint pain or swelling, muscle pain, fatigue, fever, chest pain, and mouth ulcers. There is no one test to diagnose lupus, and it may take months or years to make the diagnosis. There is no cure for lupus, but medicines and lifestyle changes can help control it.
PMC-llama13b_answer_v2: Treatment for lupus depends on the symptoms and how severe they are. Most people with lupus can control the disease with medicines.  People with mild disease may only need NSAIDs (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs) or corticosteroids.  NSAIDs include aspirin, ibuprofen, and naproxen. Corticosteroids include prednisone and hydroxychloroquine.  For more severe symptoms, doctors may prescribe antimalarial drugs, immunosuppressive drugs, and biologic agents.  Doctors may also prescribe medicines to help prevent flares and organ damage.  People with lupus may need to see different doctors. A rheumatologist is a doctor who specializes in the diseases of joints and muscles, including lupus. A nephrologist is a doctor who specializes in kidney problems. A cardiologist is a doctor who specializes in heart problems.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. The penis is not straight, but it is curved.  The penis is curved because the two long tubes (corpora cavernosa) that run the length of the penis are bent (curved).  This is due to the fact that the corpora cavernosa are covered by a layer of tissue (the tunica albuginea) which is thicker on the top of the penis than on the bottom.  The penis is not straight, but it is curved. 2. Most men have a curved penis, and this is normal.  Curved penis is not a disease and does not require any treatment. 3. A straight penis is a rare condition in which the penis bends upward or downward during erection.  A straight penis may be caused by scar tissue in the penis (Peyronie's disease) or injury to the penis.  A straight penis is a cosmetic concern, but it does not affect sexual function. 4. Treatment of straight penis includes observation, oral medications, injection of medications into the penis, and surgery.  Observation is the best option for men with a mild deformity or a straight penis that occurs infrequently.  Oral medications (vitamin E and colchicine) have been used with some success in treating straight penis.  Injection of medications (calcium chloride) into the penis can also be used to treat straight penis.  Surgery (Nesbitt's operation) may be considered for men with a severe deformity or a straight penis that occurs frequently.  Surgery involves straightening the penis by placing non-absorbable sutures in the corpus cavernosum.

It is caused by damage to the pons, usually by a lesion in the ventral part of the pons, the cerebellopontine angle, or the upper cervical spinal cord. 4. The most common cause of LIS is a stroke, but it can also result from trauma, encephalitis, poliomyelitis, or tumors. 5. The locked-in syndrome is often confused with a vegetative state (VS), catatonia, or akinetic mutism. 6. The VS and LIS share some symptoms, but VS patients are unconscious and have no cognition, while LIS patients are awake and conscious. 7. Akinetic mutism is a condition with no movement or speech, but patients are conscious and have normal cognition. 8. LIS patients are conscious, but they cannot move or communicate, while catatonia patients are unconscious and mute, but they have a normal muscle tone and reflexes. 9. Locked-in syndrome is a rare disorder, and only about 25 cases are reported in the literature. 10. The prognosis for recovery from LIS is poor, with only 20% of patients recovering.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. It is important to note that HERD is not a problem with the stomach itself. It is a problem with the lower esophageal sphincter (LES). The LES is the valve between the stomach and the esophagus. When this valve does not close properly, food and stomach acid come back up into the esophagus.2. Symptoms of HERD include: heartburn, nausea, feeling that food is stuck in the throat or esophagus, sour liquid coming out of the mouth (regurgitation), and coughing.3. HERD is usually a chronic condition. It can be aggravated by many things, including: stress, spicy foods, caffeine, alcohol, smoking, lying down after eating, and obesity.4. The goal of treatment is to control the symptoms. In many cases, diet and lifestyle changes can do this.5. Treatment may include: avoiding foods that cause symptoms, avoiding certain beverages (such as alcohol, coffee, and sodas), avoiding drugs that may cause HERD (such as certain antacids and anti-reflux drugs), and losing weight6. Other treatments may include: proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), H2 blockers, anti-reflux surgery, and antacids.7. In severe cases, surgery may be needed.

PMC-llama13b_answer_original: 1. Crossed eyes are not a disease in themselves, but a symptom of a problem with the eyes or visual system.2. The eyes are controlled by six muscles, three in each eye.3. These muscles are attached to the eyeball so that the eyes can move in six different directions.4. One of the muscles in each eye is extra strong. This muscle is called the "medial rectus." Its job is to pull the eye inward toward the nose.5. In a person with normal vision, when the eyes are looking straight ahead, the medial rectus muscle is pulling the eye straight inward.6. In a person with crossed eyes, the eye on the right side is looking inward toward the nose while the eye on the left side is looking outward toward the ear.7. This happens because the right eye's medial rectus muscle is stronger than its lateral rectus muscle, and the left eye's medial rectus muscle is weaker than its lateral rectus muscle.8. This difference in muscle strength causes the eyes to be crossed, or "cross-eyed."9. Crossed eyes can be caused by problems with the eye muscles or with the nerves that control the eye muscles.10. Problems with the eye muscles are usually present at birth. They are often caused by the baby being born too early.11. Problems with the nerves that control the eye muscles can occur later in childhood. They are often caused by damage to the brain or spinal cord.12. Crossed eyes can also be caused by problems with the bones of the eye socket or with the muscles that hold the eyes in place.13. These problems can develop at any age.14. To fix crossed eyes, the stronger eye must be made to look straight.15. In a child, this is often done with eye exercises and/or eyeglasses or contact lenses.16. In an adult, surgery is usually needed.

The condition occurs in about 2 to 4 out of every 100 children. 2. Crossed Eyes Treatment The goal of treatment for crossed eyes is to align the eyes so that a single image is seen. This is usually done by using eyeglasses or, more often, by using eyeglasses along with vision therapy exercises. 3. Vision Therapy Vision therapy is a series of exercises designed to change the way the eyes work. The goal of vision therapy is to improve eye coordination and eye focusing. With vision therapy, the eye that looks inward (the "crossed" eye) will become stronger. The weak eye will get weaker, and the "crossed" eye will straighten. 4. Surgery Surgery is another way to correct crossed eyes. It is usually done if vision therapy does not work. The surgery is done on the eye muscles. It straightens the eyes but can also weaken the eyes. 5. Prevention There is no known way to prevent crossed eyes (congenital strabismus).

PMC-llama13b_answer_v4: Multiple brain infarcts disease, also known as multi- infarct dementia, refers to cognitive impairment due to multiple areas of damage to the brain caused by interrupted blood supply.  The most common cause of interrupted blood supply is a series of small strokes.  The disorder can also result from a single large stroke.  The condition is more common in people who have high blood pressure, diabetes, or a history of smoking.  Symptoms include problems with thinking, memory, attention, learning, problem solving, and judgment.  The symptoms often get worse over time.  There is no cure.  Treatment focuses on managing the risk factors, such as high blood pressure and diabetes, and preventing future strokes.  People with this condition may have difficulty caring for themselves and require assistance.  Referral to a neurologist is recommended for further evaluation and treatment.

In case of atherosclerosis, medications such as aspirin, clopidogrel, statins, etc. are used.5. In case of embolism, medications such as warfarin are used.6. In both cases, the medications are used to prevent further episodes of stroke.7. In addition, lifestyle changes such as quitting smoking, alcohol, etc. are also important.8. In case of weakness on one side of the body, physical therapy is important.9. In case of speech problems, speech therapy is important.10. In case of memory problems, cognitive training is important.

It is the most common cause of vertigo and is usually treated by physical therapists. 2. Medications such as meclizine, dimenhydrinate, and promethazine can help reduce nausea and dizziness. 3. For people with persistent or severe symptoms, canalith repositioning procedures can be performed by an ENT specialist. 4. Surgical treatment is rarely needed and involves destruction of the inner ear structures.
